hook.text: Los Angeles in the 1940s had clear skies. Then came cars â€” and a mysterious brown haze.

buildup.text: Vehicle exhaust releases nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons into the sunny California air.

discovery.text: UV light triggers chemical reactions that produce ozone and other irritants at ground level.

twist.text: This photochemical smog is worst in hot, sunny cities â€” the opposite of London's cold fog.

climax.text: Catalytic converters on cars cut smog-forming emissions by over 90% since the 1970s.

punchline.text: LA's famous haze was cooked by sunlight from tailpipe fumes.

quiz.question: What triggers photochemical smog?
options: UV light reacting with vehicle exhaust
